channel.title: Driving License
channel.description: I just got my car driving license. it wasn't too easy but not hard. I am aiming for Motorbike in one week. I have heard that in Europe getting license is quite hard.

item.title: Driving License
item.dc:creator: Mango_Assassin
item.description:
The_Assassin47:

So then Assassin you are 18?

19(20 this november)

and @Fancy Pants, you would need to be godlike to get insured on that Jeep in this country, my little 1.3si cost me £2340 for 12 months, cheapest available.

should drop £1000 after a year without a claim, as long as I don’t hit anyone I wont claim, but if you’re under 25 in the uk your instantly considered a death threat to every road user and a carnage driver.

Read full topic

item.title: Driving License
item.dc:creator: taxi_evil
item.description:
Bolteh:

“In the European Union, vehicles from one member state do not need to display the oval while within another state, provided the number plate is in the common EU standard format, which includes the international vehicle registration code on the plate.”

Mine’s not, it’s too old

But thanks

Read full topic

item.title: Driving License
item.dc:creator: taxi_evil
item.description:
I’ve seen a few cars that already have that, mainly Volvos I think. But I should really do more research before I drive in Europe, last time I drove to Belgium I never got round to getting a GB sticker. I thought the different plate, 2 pieces of tape on the headlights and the driver in the wrong side of the car was enough of a clue

Read full topic

item.title: Driving License
item.dc:creator: johnyo
item.description:
Maxey:

You mean everyone in Latvia has to drive with lights on, always, no matter what?

Yes.

Imonfire:

I think you only have to have your headlights on when it’s night, rainy, foggy or any other condition that reduces visibility.

Depends on the country. Remember to do some research if you’re planning on driving across Europe.

Read full topic

You mean everyone in Latvia has to drive with lights on, always, no matter what?

item.title: Driving License
item.dc:creator: johnyo
item.description:
Over here headlights are obligatory 24/7 all year round. I actually think it’s good after driving abroad where that’s not the case.

Also, the license costs a shitload of money to get here. I think it’s actually slightly cheaper to get it illegally.

Read full topic

item.title: Driving License
item.dc:creator: Maxey
item.description:
Gotta love the jackasses that drive in the rain with no headlights on.

Today, during one of mechanical classes for the heavy vehicles license, I had to squat down in order to see something on an engine model and my pants ripped apart right on the crotch area.

Fortunately I’m the only student and the instructor is one of those guys that don’t make a deal out of this kind of shit.

Read full topic

item.title: Driving License
item.dc:creator: Paddy
item.description:
Thats the thing though, standard american cars (not muscle cars) have a huge engine and a fuck load of torque, but there not exactly fast, and they handle like shopping trollys. I’d much rather drive a “food blender” that grips the road and carries its speed (or lack off) into a corner. Much more fun then having to basically stop the car for a slight turn in the road.

Read full topic

item.title: Driving License
item.dc:creator: taxi_evil
item.description:
I love American cars, but I saw a Lincoln in Plymouth the other day and it’s wider than the lanes. Not really practical

I think the main difference is the epic insurance that we pay in the UK to drive anything more powerful than a food blender. I’ve just hit 21 when the price drops a bit, but my premium is still £30 more than I paid for the car, which was £600 off ebay

Read full topic
